text: a few months ago Russian official told
me that Russia and the West were locked
in a game of geopolitical chess a battle
the influence over Ukraine a zero-sum
game he called it we're both sides were
determined to emerge the victor now the
pro-eu revolution in Kiev that appear to
be disaster for Moscow and checkmate but
not quite because what happened next was
that Russia annexed the Crimea and in a
stroke the Kremlin changed the rules of
the game and the result of that is a
huge change on the ground the scale of
confrontation now between East and West
is greater than at any time since the
Cold War the rhetoric is louder the
stakes are even higher the big question
now is what will Brad Amir Putin's next
move be will the order russian troops
into southern and eastern ukraine on the
pretext of protecting russian speakers
there only he knows the answer to that
but there are things we do know for
example we know that protecting
compaction so broad is one of the
Kremlin's priorities now President Putin
has said so himself we know too that the
Russian media has been working overtime
in recent days accusing Ukraine of
violating the rights of Russian speakers
Kiev denies it we know that the Kremlin
feels cheated by the West threatened by
NATO and determined to defend what it
sees as hits sphere of influence in the
region and Russia doesn't really believe
that the West will go to war over
Ukraine and that means that the
possibility of future Russian
intervention military intervention
remains very real and so does the risk
of increasing tension between east and
west
